Award.AwardTitle: High Frequency Miniature PiezoPump For Ventricular Assist

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
High Frequency Miniature PiezoPump for Ventricular Assist

Project Summary

Congenital heart disease affects thousands of infants every year. One the most devastating subclasses of this disease are single ventricle abnormalities, in which infants are born with one functional ventricle instead two. Although researchers have used traditional electromagnetic driven ventricular assist devices to aide patients, these technologies are too bulky for children and are limited by their inability to be miniaturized without loss in power density. Thus, the premise of this proposal is that the use of piezoelectric materials in a hydraulic pump offers an alternative to traditional electromagnetic VADs.

The novelty of the proposed research plan is the development of a novel small scale high frequency piezoelectric cardiac assist device that can be used as a power source to help children with single ventricle circulations.

The intellectual merit of this proposal is the development of a fundamental understanding of the relationship between piezoelectric materials operated at high frequency and small-scale pump components. The challenge here is to effectively transfer energy from the piezoelectric to a simulated human circulation without direct blood contact.

The broader impact of this proposed research is the interdisciplinary collaboration between engineers and doctors to develop devices specifically tailored for children and patients. This research also gives underrepresented students in high school and universities an opportunity to conduct research and develop mentor style relationships with faculty and graduate students at UCLA.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Congenital heart disease affects thousands of infants every year. Although researchers have used electromagnetic driven ventricular assist devices to aide this population, these technologies are too bulky for children and are limited by their inability to be miniaturized without loss in power density. This includes but is not limited to pneumatic actuation of pulsatile blood pumps. The premise of this proposal is that the use of piezoelectric materials coupled with hydraulic power offers an alternative to traditional electromagnetic assist devices with substantially smaller form factor and better impedance matching with the human circulatory system.

 The novelty of this research is the development of an innovative miniature piezoelectric cardiac assist device to help children with heart disease. This size reduction provides the most vulnerable in our society increased mobility as they wait for a transplant

In this research, we were able to develop the first piezoelectric pump (weighing 200g) specifically designed to power pediatric pulsatile blood pumps. The device  output 500 mL/min flow,  1.3 MPa pressure, and 1.6W power output. We successfully coupled this piezohydraulic pump to a pediatric blood pump and tested the system in a setup mimicking a child’s cardiovascular circulation. We were able to produce 1 L/min flow at physiologic pressures. Future research will investigate non-linear resonant phenomena to increase piezohydraulic pump effective stroke volume leading to smaller high power actuator technologies.


Last Modified: 05/27/2015
Modified by: Greg P Carman

Image
  • The proposed piezohydraulic driven pediatric ventricular assist device system. The actual piezohydraulic pump and pediatric blood pump developed are also shown.
    John Valdovinos Ph.D.
    Greg P Carman
    Piezohydraulic Pump Ventricular Assist Device Vision
